title: When do I use 's, s', or s? - Quora

response.answer_text: When do I use 's, s', or s? Your question is a bit nebulous. I think you are asking about apostrophe rules for forming possessives, and the rules for the formation of plurals. Here are a couple of web references that may help you: Apostrophe Rules - English Grammar Rules & Usagehttps://grammar.yourdictionary.com › punctuation › apostrophe-rules Apostrophe Rules for Possessives Use an apostrophe + S ('s) to show that one person/thing owns or is a member of something. ...Use an apostrophe after the "s" at the end of a plural noun to show possession. ...If a plural noun doesn't end in "s," add an apostrophe + "s" to create the possessive form.Rules regarding the formation of plurals - English Grammarhttps://www.englishgrammar.org › rules-formation-plurals Some singular nouns ending in –o, form their plurals by simply adding –s. Nouns ending in a consonant + -y, form their plurals by changing that –y into –i and adding –es. Most nouns ending in –f or –fe form their plurals by changing –f or –fe into v and adding –es.

I believe this answer is referring to “apostrophe s,” or the “s of ownership,” because the topics for this question were quite different from what I imagined. Anyway. The The Grammar Auror™ Movement is the perfect resource to use for questions like these. Here's a link that relates to the specific question you have. Space Post I'd write more, but you can bookmark the blog post instead, Nourah. Hope this helped!
